definition: A transition element is a d block element whose atom has an incomplete d subshell, or which can give rise to cations with an incomplete d subshell.
A negative ion (anion) has more electrons than protons. It is represented by Xn−.
A positive ion (cation) has fewer electrons than protons. It is represented by Xn+.
A plasma is a gaseous mixture in which the atoms have been completely stripped of their electrons, leaving bare nuclei.

The relative atomic mass of an atom is the relative mass measured against the mass of carbon-12; it is an average value that takes into account the relative abundances of all the isotopes of that element.
The relative isotopic mass is the relative mass of a specific isotope of an element (i.e., the atomic mass of one particular isotope, measured relative to carbon-12).
The electronic configuration of an atom shows the distribution of electrons in various orbitals in an atom.
Electrons in their ground states occupy orbitals in order of energy levels; the orbital with the lowest energy is always filled first.
The effective nuclear charge, Zeff, is the net nuclear charge experienced by an outer electron.
Species are isoelectronic if they have the same number of electrons (e.g., Na+, Mg2+, Al3+ and Si4+ each have 10 electrons and are isoelectronic).
First ionisation energy is the energy needed to remove 1 mole of electrons from 1 mole of gaseous atoms to form 1 mole of unipositively charged gaseous ions.
Second ionisation energy is the energy required to remove 1 mole of electrons from 1 mole of unipositively charged gaseous ions to form 1 mole of gaseous ions with double positive charge.
The n-th ionisation energy is the energy needed to remove 1 mole of electrons from 1 mole of gaseous ions with (n−1)+ charge to form 1 mole of gaseous ions with n+ charge.
